questions.prompt: In BG 4.1, what does Krishna reveal about the origin of yoga?
choices: It was taught by Him in the beginning to the sun god
It is found only in books
It was developed gradually over time
questions.feedback: Krishna taught this yoga to Vivasvan (sun god) at the creation of the universe.

questions.prompt: What warning does BG 4.2 give about the transmission of knowledge?
questions.feedback: Over time, this succession of knowledge is lost; Krishna revives it.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.3, who recognizes Krishna's true nature and identity?
questions.feedback: Only the realized soul knows Krishna's transcendental nature.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.4, how many types of births does Krishna describe?
questions.feedback: Divine birth, demonic birth, animal birth, and plant birth.

questions.prompt: What is the significance of BG 4.5?
choices: Many take birth but few know Krishna's true nature
questions.feedback: Though Krishna appears in every millennium, few recognize His divinity.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.6, what does Krishna teach about His incarnations?
choices: He is born through His own internal energy
He is forced to take birth
questions.feedback: Krishna's appearance is not forced; He comes by His own will.

questions.prompt: BG 4.7 states that whenever there is decline of what, Krishna appears?
questions.feedback: To establish righteousness and eliminate irreligion, Krishna incarnates.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.8, what is the purpose of Krishna's advent?
choices: To deliver the pious and annihilate the wicked, and establish dharma
questions.feedback: Krishna comes to protect the righteous and punish the wicked.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.9, what is guaranteed to one who knows the transcendental nature of Krishna's appearance and activities?
choices: Liberation and return to His abode after death
questions.feedback: Understanding Krishna's true nature leads to liberation and return to godhead.

questions.prompt: What does BG 4.10 teach about those who are fully absorbed in Krishna consciousness?
choices: They suffer in the material world
They are free from fear, anger, and lust; attain Him
questions.feedback: Full surrender to Krishna purifies the heart and grants liberation.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.13, how is society organized according to the modes of nature?
choices: By the division of tasks according to qualities and work (varna)
questions.feedback: Natural qualities determine occupations and social organization.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.14, what determines one's work according to the modes of nature?
choices: Quality born of nature (guna) and work (karma) performed
questions.feedback: One's own nature and previous karma determine one's fit work.

questions.prompt: BG 4.15 asks: what is the path of those engaged in pure devotional service?
choices: Freedom from the result of work; return to the eternal kingdom
questions.feedback: Devotees are freed from karmic reactions and return to Krishna.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.16, what is the difference between action and inaction in terms of confusion?
choices: Even the wise are bewildered about what is action and what is inaction
questions.feedback: Even scholars are puzzled by the mystery of action and inaction.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.17, what characterizes work performed in knowledge?
choices: It is without attachment, ego, and produces no reaction
questions.feedback: Work done selflessly and wisely does not bind one.

questions.prompt: What does BG 4.18 teach about detachment from the results of work?
choices: Those unattached to the results, self-controlled, are freed from reactions
questions.feedback: Freedom comes from performing work without selfish desire for results.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.19, what kind of knowledge is superior?
choices: Knowledge of all work is action; understanding this is transcendental knowledge
questions.feedback: Realizing all action in the phenomenal world through Krishna's energy is supreme knowledge.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.20, what qualifies one as wise?
choices: One who understands that neither body nor senses are performing action
One who is very intelligent in worldly matters
questions.feedback: The wise understand the witness consciousness beyond bodily action.

questions.prompt: BG 4.22 states that what kind of gift is superior?
choices: One that is given at the right time to the right person with the right attitude
questions.feedback: The best gift is given in the proper spirit and at the appropriate time.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.23, what is Brahman?
choices: The ultimate reality; all action is performed by Him
questions.feedback: The Absolute Truth (Brahman) is the substratum of all activities.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.24, what is the proper understanding of sacrifice?
choices: All offering and action performed as service to the Absolute
questions.feedback: All work and offerings done for Krishna are acts of spiritual sacrifice.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.28, what are the different types of sacrifices?
choices: Some sacrifice possessions, senses, life breath, study, austerity, and yoga
questions.feedback: There are many paths of sacrifice suited to different natures.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.29, what is the greatest sacrifice?
questions.feedback: Knowledge of self (atma-jnana yajna) is the greatest sacrifice. BG 4.29 states that this sacrifice of knowledge is superior to material offerings or bodily austerities. Through transcendental knowledge, one attains the Supreme.

questions.prompt: BG 4.31 concludes that those who taste the nectar of spiritual knowledge and share it are what?
questions.feedback: Those established in knowledge attain the supreme goal.

questions.prompt: What is the main teaching of BG 4.35 about knowledge?
choices: Once you know this transcendental knowledge, no confusion remains
questions.feedback: Transcendental knowledge is the key that unlocks all doors to liberation.
